content.text: In this lesson, you'll learn how to stop a stranger and ask for simple directions in a German city. Let's start with getting someone's attention.

data.tip: The 'ch' is soft, like the 'h' in 'huge', and the 'ung' at the end sounds like 'oong'.

content.text: When speaking to strangers or in formal situations, always use the polite form of 'you', which is `Sie`.
German nouns have a gender. 'Bahnhof' is masculine, so it uses the article 'der'.

content.title: Starting the Conversation
content.setting: You're in the city center and need to find the train station. You stop a friendly-looking person.

conversation_flow.title: Ask for the train station's location

content.text: Great start! Now let's learn the words you need to understand the directions you're given.

data.tip: The 'ß' character is called an 'Eszett' and it sounds like a sharp 's'.

content.text: To confirm a street name you didn't quite hear, just repeat the name with a rising, questioning intonation.

content.title: Understanding Directions
content.setting: The person has started to give you directions. Listen carefully and ask for clarification.

conversation_flow.title: Acknowledge you understood 'left'
conversation_flow.chatbot_message: Der Bahnhof? Ah, okay. Gehen Sie hier links.

conversation_flow.title: Confirm the name of the street

content.text: You're almost there! Let's learn how to confirm the directions and end the conversation politely.
Start your sentence with `Also, ...?` to mean 'So, ...?' when you want to confirm information.

data.meaning: So, straight ahead and then right?

content.title: Finishing the Conversation
content.setting: You've understood the main directions. Now, confirm them and thank the person for their help.

conversation_flow.title: Repeat the directions to confirm
conversation_flow.chatbot_message: Ja, Schillerstraße. Gehen Sie geradeaus und dann rechts.

conversation_flow.title: Thank the person
conversation_flow.chatbot_message: Ja, genau! Der Bahnhof ist dann da.
